body:
### bombs for the masses
A decompression bomb is a file designed to crash or render useless the program or system reading it, i.e. a denial of service. The following files can be used to test whether an application is vulnerable to this type of attack. 

***
**Archives**
| Format  | Archive Size | Compression Ratio |
| ------------- | ------------- | ------------- |
| [bzip2](http://www.bzip.org/)  | 7KB  | ~1427411:1 |
| [xar](https://code.google.com/archive/p/xar/) (bzip2) | 9KB | ~1198921:1  |
| [7z](http://www.7-zip.org/7z.html) | 1.5MB | ~6848:1 |
| [xz](http://tukaani.org/xz/format.html) | 1.5MB | ~6875:1 |
| [Gzip](https://www.gnu.org/software/gzip/) | 10.2MB | ~1029:1 |
| [ZIP](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zip_(file_format)) | 10.2MB | ~1029:1 |
| [LZ4](https://cyan4973.github.io/lz4/) | 41.2MB | ~258:1 |
> Ratios calculated from a zero-generated 10GB file: `dd if=/dev/zero of=10GB bs=1024 count=0 seek=$[1024*10000]`
